replies.body: You have to learn what's the best way for you to kill a player in a 1v1 combat, practice is the only way to get better. You can develop a better experience, and you can try different techniques to what is suitable for you. Practice different styles!

replies.body:
Which faze? :d
On topic: You can use others as a building block to get up; but you usually get used to some sort of playstyle and you mold it to your use. That's what happened to me anyways.
Watch some YT'ers, watch how they play and mold it into your playstyle.

Train yourself kid.

look up videos on youtube.

Here's a tip: when fighting someone, jump around them whilst strafing. Doing this allows you to hit him and bascially get behind him and hit him again.

replies.body: I'd teach you if you wanted. But I'm ez :p. The best way to learn is to watch videos by good pvpers and try and incorporate their tactics into your pvp. The best way to do this is practice. Watch people like Cayden, pmpheys, 0scavenge0, Stimpay, UnPhair and ApacheBlitz
replies.body_tagged: I'd teach you if you wanted. But I'm ez :p. The best way to learn is to watch videos by good pvpers and try and incorporate their tactics into your pvp. The best way to do this is practice. Watch people like Cayden, pmpheys, 0scavenge0, Stimpay, UnPhair and ApacheBlitz

replies.body:
Watch videos and practice. I managed to get myself from a 0.8 KD at the beginning of Avicus to a 4.99 KD right now.

Also depends on what you want to get good at. I'm best at bow because I've been playing Nebula and TF2 (in Minecraft) for so long, so I'm "training" to be better with swordplay by doing Soup. Hunger games mostly revolves around swordplay, but it requires you to be a bit smart in terms of hunger/inventory management, facing teams, and being aware of your surroundings in order to find/avoid players and keep yourself from getting lost. So play different minigames depending on the aspect you want to work on.

And btw, every opponent you face is practically a trainer, whether you shrek them or they shrek you.
replies.body_tagged:
Watch videos and practice. I managed to get myself from a 0.8 KD at the beginning of Avicus to a 4.99 KD right now.

Also depends on what you want to get good at. I'm best at bow because I've been playing Nebula and TF2 (in Minecraft) for so long, so I'm "training" to be better with swordplay by doing Soup. Hunger games mostly revolves around swordplay, but it requires you to be a bit smart in terms of hunger/inventory management, facing teams, and being aware of your surroundings in order to find/avoid players and keep yourself from getting lost. So play different minigames depending on the aspect you want to work on.

And btw, every opponent you face is practically a trainer, whether you shrek them or they shrek you.

replies.body: I'm not a pvp mlgee pro, but the best I can give you is don't rely too heavily on block hitting. I see a lot of people running in just block hittin' all the way and expecting that to win all their fights for them.  The second somebody some along who knows how to counter it, they just fail, and you can kill them while keeping a full health bar.
replies.body_tagged: I'm not a pvp mlgee pro, but the best I can give you is don't rely too heavily on block hitting. I see a lot of people running in just block hittin' all the way and expecting that to win all their fights for them.  The second somebody some along who knows how to counter it, they just fail, and you can kill them while keeping a full health bar.

replies.body: My advice would be to left click a lot, and occasionally use the wasd keys on your keyboard. That's just my opinion tho.
replies.body_tagged: My advice would be to left click a lot, and occasionally use the wasd keys on your keyboard. That's just my opinion tho.

replies.body: I don't ask people to train me but I do ask why I was killed and what I did wrong in battle so I can get better. A thing to remember is you will always die, no matter what tactic you use you will die training at it so don't give up just because you die heaps of times.
replies.body_tagged: I don't ask people to train me but I do ask why I was killed and what I did wrong in battle so I can get better. A thing to remember is you will always die, no matter what tactic you use you will die training at it so don't give up just because you die heaps of times.

jk jk :)


In all seriousness, you can't really train at pvp. Maybe clicking a bunch of times,clicking exercises, osu will help train at pvp but i do not think they cannot train you at pvp. You can train yourself by 1v1 pvp matches or some youtube video's :/

replies.body: A tip from me would be, don't be a block hitting noob, PvP properley with strafing and combos, block hitting is the lamest.
replies.body_tagged: A tip from me would be, don't be a block hitting noob, PvP properley with strafing and combos, block hitting is the lamest.

replies.body:
But you know what's worst, being predictable. Block hitting might sounds nooby, but is easily counterable, so don't complain about it, enjoy the free kills.

I would personally recommend doing both depending the situation, but the most important part is, have style, be unpredictable, be even more godly than latiku or cenation, and do crazy stuff, you'll think about what you did after you did it, don't take time thinking before going ham!
